speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.5: Curriculum Update - The board will consider adoption of a new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8, aligned with updated state standards. The proposed curriculum includes digital resources, project-based learning activities, and teacher training components. Adoption is intended to improve student outcomes in algebra readiness and standardized test performance.. Who would like to start?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I think we should look at this more closely. What makes you believe that adopting a new math program will help our students do better on standardized tests? We have tried so many different programs over the years, and they all promise similar results but don't always deliver. Can we see some data comparing these materials to what we currently use? And how much does it cost?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Kate, thank you for your thoughtful questions. I share your concerns about the need for evidence-based decision making. In fact, our district has conducted a thorough review of the current research on math education, and the findings support the shift towards a more integrated approach to teaching math concepts, which is exactly what this new curriculum offers. As for cost, I'd be happy to provide those figures. According to our estimates, the total investment for the three-year implementation period comes out to approximately $250,000, broken down into professional development, materials, and technology infrastructure upgrades. That works out to roughly an additional $83 per student per year. Considering the potential long-term benefits, I believe it's a worthwhile investment. Would anyone else like to weigh in

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Okay. I was going to say something when Ellen mentioned that figure because while 83 dollars sounds relatively low compared to everything, it adds up really quickly when you multiply by every single kid in the school. So my question there too would just be how we're planning on finding money within our existing budget, right? Because as far as I'm aware, we haven't had any conversations yet about having excess funds or having extra funds available in next year's budget. How can we afford it if we were to vote for this tonight?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Katrina, excellent point! You're absolutely right; $83 per student may seem manageable, but indeed, it does add up quickly. I appreciate your diligence in keeping us grounded in fiscal reality. To answer your question, I'd like to propose exploring reallocation options within our existing budget. Perhaps we could revisit line items related to textbook purchases or other resource allocations and redirect them towards funding this new math curriculum. Additionally, we might consider partnering with local businesses or foundations to secure grant opportunities that could offset some of the costs. I agree we shouldn't make decisions without a clear plan for financing, so let's task our administration to come back to us with concrete suggestions for covering the expenses before we move forward with the adoption.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I totally agree with both Kate and Katrina. These proposals sound great on paper, but then again, most do until we get hit with sticker shock. I want to know what happens after these initial three years. Are we looking at ongoing annual expenditures for licensing fees, updates, and further staff training? It seems like we're constantly chasing one magic bullet solution after another. Can someone explain to me why this won't end up being yet another flash-in-the-pan initiative that drains our resources before disappearing from view?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Is it true that this particular program has been proven effective in districts with demographics close to ours?

speaker: judyle
content: I understand David's concern about sustainability beyond the initial three years. However, I think we also need to acknowledge that doing nothing isn't an option either. Our students' math scores aren't where they should be, and simply maintaining the status quo isn't going to magically fix the problem. While it's true that past initiatives may not have delivered as promised, that doesn't mean we give up on trying to find solutions. This proposal has some promising elements – digital resources, project-based learning, and teacher training – which suggest a more comprehensive approach than we've seen before. Before we dismiss it entirely, can we explore ways to ensure accountability and regular assessment of its effectiveness during and beyond the three-year mark? Maybe we could build in benchmarks or check

speaker: kateacuff
content: Just to clarify, Judy, regarding building in benchmarks, wouldn't we already have assessments built into whatever curriculum we adopt? Why do we need additional layers of evaluation? Plus, wasn't part of the justification for adopting a new curriculum that our kids weren't performing well on standardized tests anyway? Shouldn't we focus on fixing the underlying issues rather than throwing more tests their way?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Kate, I understand your point about not wanting to overwhelm our students with excessive testing. However, I think Judy's suggestion about building in benchmarks is meant to serve a slightly different purpose. Rather than adding more high-stakes testing, perhaps we could implement smaller-scale, formative assessments throughout the year to gauge the effectiveness of this new curriculum. This would allow us to identify areas where adjustments need to be made and make data-driven decisions to refine our approach. It's not about piling on more tests, but rather using targeted evaluations to inform instruction and ensure we're moving in the right direction. Does that clarify things?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I see what you're saying now, Ellen. My issue still remains though: If we're committing to spending a quarter million dollars on this curriculum, shouldn't we expect to see some meaningful returns on that investment? How are we defining success here, and what guarantees do we have that this new curriculum will actually lead to improved student outcomes? It feels like we're crossing our fingers and hoping for the best instead of insisting on tangible results.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Kate, I completely understand your skepticism, and I apologize if our presentation hasn't adequately addressed your concerns. Let me try to provide more clarity. The vendor has committed to working closely with us to establish specific, measurable goals and key performance indicators (KPIs) that will help us track progress and evaluate the effectiveness of this new curriculum. They'll also provide dedicated support and coaching for our teachers to ensure successful implementation. Furthermore, we'll conduct regular reviews and assessments to monitor student growth and adjust our strategies accordingly. I agree that we must hold ourselves accountable for delivering tangible results, and I'm willing to work with our administrative team to develop a detailed dashboard that tracks our progress toward those KPIs. Would that alleviate some of your concerns?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, Ellen, I appreciate your willingness to address my reservations, but how binding are these commitments, and what kind of teeth do they have? What I mean is, what happens if the vendor fails to deliver or we don't meet those targets? Do we have contractual provisions that would enable us to reevaluate or even opt out of the agreement? We can't keep investing time, energy, and taxpayer money without consequences if the desired outcomes don't materialize.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Ah, Kate, you're getting down to brass tacks, and I love it. You're right; we need to protect our district's interests and ensure we're not locked into a bad deal. Let me tell you, I've negotiated with vendors enough times to know that contracts matter. In this case, I insisted that we include performance clauses that tie payment milestones to achieving specific metrics. If the vendor falls short or we don't see satisfactory progress, we have the right to withhold payments or renegotiate terms. And if all else fails, we can terminate the contract with reasonable notice. Make no mistake, Kate, I've got our backs covered. We're not signing away our autonomy or committing to a sinking ship. We'll enter into

speaker: kateacuff
content: Now I feel better, Ellen. Thank you for clarifying that. It's crucial we have safeguards in place when making significant financial commitments like this.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Absolutely, Kate! As a board, it's our fiduciary duty to be responsible stewards of our district's funds. I'm glad we could have this open discussion and iron out any concerns. Now, shall we move forward with a vote on whether to approve the proposed curriculum adoption?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote publicly.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.5: Should the district adopt the proposed new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8?.  Ms. Acuff, can you please start us off?

speaker: kateacuff
content: yes

content: Ms. Acuff votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Acuff.

content: Ms. Osborne votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Osborne.

content: To begin with, my thanks go to both Ms. Acuff and Ms. Osborne for their thoughtful questions during this conversation, which helped clarify some important aspects of this proposal.
